Bundles and Database Transactions

Lesson
objectives

¢ Describe bundle context

Differentiate between read-only and writable
bundles

Utilize API methods for creating and
committing bundles

Add and/or edit entity instances in a bundle
Reference original values for edited entity
instance fields

Understand bundle best practices for
integration

| Bundles Gi

g

aBankAcount

aFlagEntry

XN

aLegalCase

* To manage database transactions, Guidewire applications group entity instances
in groups called bundles

¢ A bundle is an in-memory container for entity instances that represent rows in the
database

« Includes new entity instances, changed entity instances, and retired entity instances

| Entity instances

¢ Java objects that represent

¢ To view an existing entity instance —eon

1.

Read entity instance from the database into the application
server

Put them in a bundle
Modify them in the bundle

. Commit the bundle of changes back to the database

instance a @S,

¢ But performing a query for every accessor would be far too

expensive | y
* Each one is cheap but they add up @
* The solution is two levels of caching

¢ The first level is the bundle which represents local cache
* The second level is the application server global cache

| Bundle types

¢ Entity instances retrieved from a database
query

referenced by an entity instance in a read-
only bundle

Entity instances that are being edited or
retired in the user interface, an application
process, or in code

Entity instances you intend to create or
modify in the database must first exist or be
added in a writable bundle

writable bundle G mo

| Bundle context Gi

¢ Application creates current bundle to —*_— Integration code creates bundle
create, read, update, and/or retire explicitly
data

* Contains entity instances available
to the current code context

* Code determines bundle contents
¢ New bundles are writable

¢ Read-only or writable

mm lgrY

| Committing a bundle

Bundle

* Commits are transactional
+ All DB changes occur in a transaction, and succeed or fail as a group

+ A failure of any entity instance in the bundle to successfully commit will cause changes or additions to
any entity instance in the bundle to be rolled back

+ In most situations bundle commits are automatic unless you are controlling the bundle
+ Because you created the bundle

* Or you've taken over control of the Current bundle

| Automatic bundle processing

Explicit bundle manipulation is not required
In:

Business rules

Workflows

Certain plugins

Changes made through the user Interface

In the above contexts, bundle manipulation On
is handled by the application ny
Changes, Additions, Retires are committed

to the database at an appropriate time
depending on context

| Manual bundle processing

* Your code must explicitly manage
bundles for:

« Web services that make DB changes
* Batch processes that make DB changes

* Modifications to entities returned from
queries

* Certain plugins

| Gosu capabilities with bundles Gi

Create new bundles « Remove an entity instance from a bundle
Modify entity instances in writable * Modify entity instances in a read-only
bundles bundle

Identify whether an entity instance in a * Copy a newly created entity instance
bundle has changed since it was read from one bundle to another

from the DB + From a bundle perspective new entity

Copy unchanged entity instances from instances are treated as “changed”

one bundle to another

Commit a bundle

Working with bundles

| Committing the current bundle

* gw.transaction.Transaction.getCurrent ()
* Gets current bundle

* bundle.commit ()
* Commits every entity instance in the bundle

¢ Make sure that the Commit is appropriate for the
programming context
¢ The Current bundle contains data known to the current context,

such as entity instances being presented/changed in the user
interface

* Committing data inappropriately can cause data integrity problems

design

context will automatically be added to <+. Ss

No code block

bundle. commit ()

entity instance or changed
entity instance

>

uses trainingapp.base.QueryUtil
uses gw.transaction.Transaction

var targetPerson = QueryUtil.findPerson("ab:5")
var newBundle = Transaction. nevBundle()
targetPerson = newBundle.add(targetPerson)
targetPerson.MiddleName = "John"

newBundle. commit ()

| Original values Gi

¢ Prior to the commit, Gosu retains a copy of each entity instance read from the
database

¢ Several properties and methods let you work with the original data in the entity
instance
* entityName.Changed
+ Returns true if any property on the entity instance has changed
* entityName. isFieldChanged (Entity#FieldName)
+ Returns true if a property has changed since the entity instance was read from database

* entityName.getOriginalValue (Entity#FieldName.getPropertyInfo()as
IEntityPropertyInfo)

+ Returns property value read from database

| Using original values example Gi

private static function createABCompanyNoteForInspection(targetCompany: ABCompany, inspectionDat
var hasInspectionDateChanged = targetCompany. isFieldChanged (ABCompanyéInspectionDate)
if (nasInspectionDateChanged) {
var newNote = new ContactNote ()
newllote. Subject = "Change to inspection date”
newNlote.ContactNoteType = typekey.ContactNlotelype. 7¢_DATA_UPDATE
var originalInspectionDate = targetCompany.getOriginalValue (ABCompany#InspectionDate.getPropertyInfo() as IEntityPropertyInfo)
newNote.Body = String. format("Inspection date updated from #s to #s ", {originalInspectionDate, targetCompany.InspectionDate})
return newNote
} else
return null

| Updating the Database Gi

No Current Bundle for integration resources
Use Transaction. runWithNewBundle(/ bundle ->{}) or
Transaction.newBundle ()
If you expect to update large numbers of entities:
“Large number of entities” is a relative term
Consider using paging with regular commits
Keep bundle sizes as small as practicable
Be careful about how you use accessors

Use Query best practices
+ Do filtering at the database rather than in memory — Let the DB do what it’s good at

+ See “Guidewire Query API” lesson for more information

| Updating the Database in a Batch Process

¢ Simple minded approach:

6 gw.transaction.Transaction. runWithNewBundle(\ newBundle -> {
7 queryResults.each(\ oneResult -> {

8 var tyToM = newBundle.add(oneResult)

9 //

10 )

11 }, username)

* Two main problems:

« Memory

¢ Bundle performance

Every new accessor retrieves an entity into the bundle
Using accessors from those entities retrieves more entities

Bundles can grow very large

| A Better Approach: Paging Plus Regular Commits

¢ Better approach:

— var pageSize = 10000
—> var chunkSize = 250
results. set PageSize (pageSize)
for( entities in com.google.common.collect.Iterables.partition(results, chunkSize) )
gw.transaction.Transaction. runWithNewBundle( \ bundle -> {
for( e in entities) {

var Modify = bundle.add(e)

}
}, username )

¢ Page size: 10,000
¢ Bundle size: 250

{

| Paging Plus Regular Commits — Considerations Gi

¢ Optimal page and bundle sizes will vary with specific tables, queries, DB’s, and
environments

* There is no one size fits all
* Performance testing can be very revealing
¢ Still likely to be slow for big queries
« Paging doesn’t work well with some types of modification

* Modifying columns you queried on repositions the cursor

Question

_- — Whatis a bundle?

¢
¢
¢

Seo e Soe esses see see

Answer

_- — What is a bundle?
¢

¢
¢

A Guidewire bundle is a set of in-memory entities that are saved to the database as a
unit. Each bundle corresponds to one database transaction.

Soo eS eee soe ese ese

B) Code executed from the UI in edit mode

Question G

_- — What kind of entities are initially put into read-only bundles?
Pa Under what circumstance would you need to copy one of those entities
: to a writable bundle and how is this done?

Seo e Soe esses see see

Answer Gi

_— — What kind of entities are initially put into read-only bundles?
Pa Under what circumstance would you need to copy one of those entities
: to a writable bundle and how is this done?

Entities that are the result of a query are put into read-only bundles, and entities
referenced by foreign key are put into a read-only bundle if the referencing entity is
also in a read-only bundle.

You need to copy these entities to a writable bundle if you need to modify them, which
is done via the bundle's add method.

Soo eS eee soe ese ese

instance fields

| Original values Gi

¢ Prior to the commit, Gosu retains a copy of each entity instance read from the
database

¢ Several properties and methods let you work with the original data in the entity
instance
* entityName.Changed
+ Returns true if any property on the entity instance has changed
* entityName. isFieldChanged (Entity#FieldName)
+ Returns true if a property has changed since the entity instance was read from database

* entityName.getOriginalValue (Entity#FieldName.getPropertyInfo()as
IEntityPropertyInfo)

+ Returns property value read from database

| Updating the Database Gi

No Current Bundle for integration resources
Use Transaction. runWithNewBundle(/ bundle ->{}) or
Transaction.newBundle ()
If you expect to update large numbers of entities:
“Large number of entities” is a relative term
Consider using paging with regular commits
Keep bundle sizes as small as practicable
Be careful about how you use accessors

Use Query best practices
+ Do filtering at the database rather than in memory — Let the DB do what it’s good at

+ See “Guidewire Query API” lesson for more information

| Updating the Database in a Batch Process

¢ Simple minded approach:

6 gw.transaction.Transaction. runWithNewBundle(\ newBundle -> {
7 queryResults.each(\ oneResult -> {

8 var tyToM = newBundle.add(oneResult)

9 //

10 )

11 }, username)

* Two main problems:

« Memory

¢ Bundle performance

Every new accessor retrieves an entity into the bundle
Using accessors from those entities retrieves more entities

Bundles can grow very large

| Paging Plus Regular Commits — Considerations Gi

¢ Optimal page and bundle sizes will vary with specific tables, queries, DB’s, and
environments

* There is no one size fits all
* Performance testing can be very revealing
¢ Still likely to be slow for big queries
« Paging doesn’t work well with some types of modification

* Modifying columns you queried on repositions the cursor

Question

_- — Whatis a bundle?

Answer

_- — What is a bundle?
¢

¢
¢

A Guidewire bundle is a set of in-memory entities that are saved to the database as a
unit. Each bundle corresponds to one database transaction.

Question G

_- — What kind of entities are initially put into read-only bundles?
Pa Under what circumstance would you need to copy one of those entities
: to a writable bundle and how is this done?

Seo e Soe esses see see

Answer Gi

_— — What kind of entities are initially put into read-only bundles?
Pa Under what circumstance would you need to copy one of those entities
: to a writable bundle and how is this done?

Entities that are the result of a query are put into read-only bundles, and entities
referenced by foreign key are put into a read-only bundle if the referencing entity is
also in a read-only bundle.

You need to copy these entities to a writable bundle if you need to modify them, which
is done via the bundle's add method.
